headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call.As a reminder, this call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chief Financ
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call.
As a reminder, this call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing second quarter 2015 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-loo
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing second quarter 2015 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-looking statements have been outlined in the earnings release in EOG's SEC filings, and we incorporate those by reference for this call. This conference call also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation schedules for these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures can be found on our website at www.eogresources.com. The SEC permits oil and gas companies in their filings with the SEC to disclose not only proved reserves, but also probable reserves as well as possible reserves. Some of the reserve estimates on this conference call and webcast may include potential reserves or other estimated reserves not necessarily calculated in accordance with or contemplated by the SEC's reserve reporting guidelines. We incorporate by reference the cautionary note to U.S. investors that appears at the bottom of our press release.
Participating on the call this morning are, Bill Thomas, Chairman and CEO; Gary Thomas, President and Chief Operating Officer; Billy Helms, EVP Exploration and Production; David Trice, EVP Exploration and Production; Lance Terveen, VP Marketing Operations; and Cedrick Burgher, Senior VP, Investor and Public Relations.
An updated IR presentation was posted to our website yesterday evening, and we included guidance for the third quarter and full year 2015 in yesterday's press release. This morning, we'll discuss topics in the following order: Bill Thomas will update our 2015 2013 plan, David Trice and Billy Helms will review operational results; I will then discuss EOG's financials, capital structure and hedge position, and Bill will provide concluding remarks. Here's Bill Thomas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. We're pleased with the performance from our spacing tests using our integrated completion processing the Bakken. We now estimate that our Bakken and Three Forks total net resource potential is just over 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent. T
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. We're pleased with the performance from our spacing tests using our integrated completion processing the Bakken. We now estimate that our Bakken and Three Forks total net resource potential is just over 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent. That's almost 2.5x our original estimate of 420 million barrels of oil equivalent. Remaining drilling inventory increased from 580 to over 1,500 net drilling locations. This represents 760 million barrels of oil equivalent that remaining net potential reserves and decades of drilling in this premier North Dakota asset. In addition to the updated resource estimates, we split the Bakken into 2 categories that we have titled Core Acreage And Non-Core Acreage. The core produces returns that are competitive with both the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin, and includes our acreage in the Bakken core and Antelope Extension. Non-core represents acreage in the Bakken Light State Line and areas. Although our main focus will be in the core area, we believe that with modern high density completions and current well costs, the non-core acreage will be very economic even with low oil prices. 
We defined 120,000 net acres and 590 net drilling locations in the core, which represents remaining net resource potential of 360 million barrels of oil equivalent. This inventory alone offers over 10 years of drilling. Non-core acreage represents remaining net resource potential of 400 million barrels equivalent. In this acreage, we defined 110,000 net acres and 950 [ph] net drilling locations, which provide decades of inventory. Our wells in the Bakken continue to exceed expectations. A great example of the progress we're making is the Riverview 102 32H well. This is the first Bakken well in the Antelope Extension we have drilled using a high density completion. The well came on online with a maximum rate of 3,395 barrels of oil per day and 6 million cubic feet of rich natural gas, with an average rate of 2,760 barrels of oil per day for July, this short 4,300-foot lateral will be the highest rate oil well ever recorded for the Bakken or Three Forks. We are excited to continue applying high density completions throughout the entire play as we move forward. 
In addition to improve returns to advance completion, we've made tremendous progress on Bakken completed well costs, which are now $7.1 million for an 8,400-foot tree lateral. This is almost 20% decrease in well costs from 2014. Most of the well cost savings are due to efficiency gains rather than vendor cost reductions and therefore, should be sustainable over time. Drilling times are now averaging 8.2 days spread the TV for an 8,400-foot lateral with our best being a record 5.6 days. We are also realizing significant completion efficiencies. Currently, we are averaging more than 10 completion status per day, up from 4 to 5 status per day in 2014. In addition, plug drill out times have been cut in half since 2014. Finally, cost savings are not just limited to CapEx. We added infrastructure this year in the Bakken core and as a result, we have seen dramatic LOE reproductions. Second quarter LOE is down more than 25% from the first quarter. The increase to our Bakken reserve potential and drilling inventory, illustrates the value of EOG's exploration and technology leadership. We interplay as the first mover and capture the best assets, then we grow them to the drillbit and improve recoveries over time with drilling and completion technology developed in-house. This is how EOG continues to grow organically. 
Here's Billy Helms to update you on the Delaware Basin and the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. The plays in the Delaware Basin are also proving to be very good examples of how EOG is repositioning itself to generate strong returns in this period of low commodity prices. We have made improvements to productivity while significantly lo
componenttext:
Thanks, David. The plays in the Delaware Basin are also proving to be very good examples of how EOG is repositioning itself to generate strong returns in this period of low commodity prices. We have made improvements to productivity while significantly lowering completed well cost. In the case of improved productivity, we are finding that wellbore targeting along with our integrated completion approach continues to provide upside on well performance. 
In the second quarter, we maintained our activity in the Second Bone Spring Sand, testing various spacing patterns and targets. Two recent wells, the Dragon 36 State #501H and 502H were completed in a 1,000-foot space pattern with initial production rates of 1,075 and 1,755 barrels of oil per day. Another recent completion in Lea County, New Mexico, the Frazier 34 State Com #501H tested 1,705 barrels of oil per day with 145 barrels per day of NGLs and 1.1 million cubic feet per day of natural gas. 
The completed well costs for the Second Bone Spring Sand are currently averaging $6 million per well, representing a 22% reduction from last year's average. A major portion of the cost savings can be attributed to sustainable efficiency improvements in both drilling and completion operations rather than solely vendor cost reductions. Improved well performance, coupled with lower well cost, make this play very attractive in this lower commodity price environment. We will continue evaluating well performance to determine the proper spacing and ultimate recovery. 
During the last quarter, we also completed several strong Wolfcamp wells in the over pressured, oil window of the play. Two recent completions in Lea County, New Mexico, the Dragon 36 States #701H and the Hern's 27 State Comp #703H had initial production rates per well of 2,650 barrels of oil per day along with 285 barrels per day of NGLs and 1.9 million cubic feet per day of natural gas. As we evaluate various target and spacing patterns, this play promises to be a higher return growth asset for EOG. 
Similar advancements have been achieved in the Leonard play. A typical well now costs $5.5 million and we are testing spacing patterns of 300 feet and 500 feet between wells, 1 recent completion in Lee County, New Mexico, the Jim 36 State Comp #1H had an initial production rate of 2,200 barrels of oil per day, 460 barrels per day of NGLs and 2.6 million cubic feet per day of natural gas. Our downspacing efforts demonstrate that we can drill wells closer together without sacrificing production. These new completion designs are allowing us to improve the overall economics and ultimate recovery. 
Due to these strong results, we anticipate the Delaware Basin will play a significant role in EOG's long-term growth. As typical with our other place, EOG is -- will evaluate options and invest in the infrastructure needed to serve future production growth while keeping our long-term operating costs to a minimum. We are very excited about the opportunities and growth potential for EOG's Delaware Basin properties. 
Now moving to the Eagle Ford, which continues to be our work course asset. Due to the sheer scale of our operations there, it functions as a laboratory for technical progress, on target selection, geosteering and high density completion designs. To support our wellbore targeting efforts this year, we drilled 4 pilot wells together with additional log data and provide a more complete picture of our acreage. This information greatly enhances our understanding of any specific targets variability across the play. We are currently conducting tests using a staggered W pattern in the lower Eagle Ford and the new data we gathered on the targets is encouraging, as it supports our expectations for success. 
While it's too early to share results, we are excited about the benefits our targeting efforts can have on our Eagle Ford drilling program and ultimate field recovery. We are also pleased with the progress that cost-reduction efforts in the Eagle Ford. Our average completed well cost is currently $5.5 million and headed toward our 2015 goal of $5.3 million. Similar to our other plays, most of these cost reductions are being achieved through efficiency gains and should be sustainable. Also, the productivity of the wells continues to show steady improvement through our emphasis on targeting and high density completions. Some of the recent wells are highlighted in our press release. The combination of cost reductions and better well performance through the application of technology, is ensuring that this world class asset will continue to deliver stronger growth for years to come. 
I'll now turn it over to Tim Driggers to discuss financials and capital structure

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Billy. Capitalized interest for the second quarter 2015 was $11 million. Total cash exploration of development expenditures were $1.2 billion, excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems
componenttext:
Thanks, Billy. Capitalized interest for the second quarter 2015 was $11 million. Total cash exploration of development expenditures were $1.2 billion, excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $85 million. 
At the end of June 2015, total debt outstanding was $6.4 billion and the debt to total capitalization ratio was 27%. At June 30, we had $1.4 billion of cash on hand, giving us non-GAAP net debt of $5 billion for a net debt to total capital ratio of 22%. In April, Moody's confirmed EOG's A3 rating with a stable outlook. In July, we successfully entered into a new $2 billion credit agreement to replace the existing one, which would've matured in October 2016. Terms of the new agreement were similar to the prior credit agreement. 
The effective tax rate for the second quarter was 146% and current tax expense was $41 million. For the period August 1 through December 31, 2015, EOG has crude oil financial price swaps contracts in place for 10,000 barrels of oil per day at a weighted average price of $89.98 per barrel. For the second -- I'm sorry, for the period September 1 through December 31, 2015, EOG has natural gas financial price swap contracts in place for 575,000 MMBtu per day at a weighted average price of $4.51 per MMBtu. These numbers exclude options that are exercisable by our counterparties. 
Now I'll turn it back over to Bill.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, I wanted to start with a macro question if I may, because you guys have obviously, done a phenomenal job of getting your cost down, your efficiency improvements and I think a couple of this plays really speak to the depth of the portfolio. But it se
componenttext: Bill, I wanted to start with a macro question if I may, because you guys have obviously, done a phenomenal job of getting your cost down, your efficiency improvements and I think a couple of this plays really speak to the depth of the portfolio. But it seems that you're making a macro decision based on oil price here and no one else seems to be taking the same view. In other words, you're foregoing production growth, and a lot of your peers with lesser economics are continuing to pursue drills. So I'm just wondering if you can help us reconcile your macro thoughts with the stock-specific opportunities you have in the portfolio. And I guess with the view to 2016, and I I've got a follow-up.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. Our macro view is we think, a pretty solid view. We do a lot of work and a lot of study on the process and we, particularly model what everybody is saying in the U.S. and what they're going to be doing in the second half of this year through th
componenttext: Yes, Doug. Our macro view is we think, a pretty solid view. We do a lot of work and a lot of study on the process and we, particularly model what everybody is saying in the U.S. and what they're going to be doing in the second half of this year through their guidance. And we really believe that in the second part of this year, we're going to see some strong month over month decline rate. And it may take -- it will take probably at least 2 or 3 more months for the monthly numbers to confirm this. There's a 2-month lag in the data and the date does not -- as we know, not precise and it gets updated over time. So what we really need to see to confirm this is the July and August monthly data. And that'll come in, in September and October. So hopefully by that time, the declines will be a bit more evident to everybody. And if that happens, we could see a bit more firmness in the price. So our model shows, by what everybody is guiding, that the U.S. will grow about 500,000 to 600,000 barrels a day this year versus the 1.2 million barrels a day, last year, so there's a significant drop off in the year-over-year growth rate. And then if the -- if prices continue to stay low through the end of the year, we expect 2016 to have continued month over month decline rates in the U.S. and that will be joined by decline rates in other non-OpEx [ph] supply in 2016. And the combination of those things with the continued reasonable demand growth gives a decent opportunity for prices to be a bit better than they are right now in 2016. So certainly, that was a factor in our decision to defer spending capital, trying to accelerate oil in the current market. The other thing is certainly is that we just can't see a good business reason to outspend growing oil in an oversupplied oil market. That does not make sense to us, so we believe we made the right decision.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, I admire the discipline. I don't want to belabor this point, but I guess what I'm thinking is if I look at Slide 5, you got a -- you clearly have better returns today for example, in the Leonard than you did when oil was substantially higher, which
componenttext: Bill, I admire the discipline. I don't want to belabor this point, but I guess what I'm thinking is if I look at Slide 5, you got a -- you clearly have better returns today for example, in the Leonard than you did when oil was substantially higher, which obviously, fits your incentive structure to attract returns. I guess, what I'm really kind of thinking is if, let's assume that you're wrong and oil prices don't recover because consensus seems to be more for longer, would you go back to growth in 2016?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me follow up on your 2016 comments and I appreciate your asset position and the budget you have today. Philosophically, I mean, if it's necessary to stay within cash flow in the 2016, are you willing to go into annual production declines? Or is that w
componenttext: Let me follow up on your 2016 comments and I appreciate your asset position and the budget you have today. Philosophically, I mean, if it's necessary to stay within cash flow in the 2016, are you willing to go into annual production declines? Or is that where you would consider drawing ducts or moving to an outspend?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: The question there, Evan, is yes, with grow production. We're not inclined to grow production just in a continued low price environment, but like what Bill is saying, we're very well positioned with all of our high-quality ducts, wells not completed and w
componenttext: The question there, Evan, is yes, with grow production. We're not inclined to grow production just in a continued low price environment, but like what Bill is saying, we're very well positioned with all of our high-quality ducts, wells not completed and we're going to end the year with 15 to 18 drilling rigs and we'll only have 13 under long contract next year. So in order to go ahead and just to at least maintain, possibly grow production, depending on what the prices are, we'll start with quite a number of completion units and that just -- that allows us to bring production on rapidly and also be able to do it at low-cost with all the reduced costs we've had from just increased efficiencies here through 2015.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015

componenttext: We've maintained our production as far as domestic just flat here and that's kind of what we guide here through 2015, so that's probably likely for '16.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: My second one, if I could, on the high density completions. I mean, you guys are clearly the leader here. It's 95% Eagle Ford wells this year, you've begun in the Bakken with now a very strong handle on extension oil, implement the Second Bone Springs, wi
componenttext: My second one, if I could, on the high density completions. I mean, you guys are clearly the leader here. It's 95% Eagle Ford wells this year, you've begun in the Bakken with now a very strong handle on extension oil, implement the Second Bone Springs, with this quarter, last quarter, Wolfcamp in the 3Q [ph] and Leonard, since the beginning of the year. I mean, can you walk me through how long it takes you to substantially implement those designs across your Delaware and Bakken positions? I'm just wondering how we should think about how long it takes to get to a similar percentage of high density completions as you have in the Eagle Ford and the rest of your portfolio?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Evan, we've seen this work so well throughout all of our plays. We're under implementation currently. So it's in place and we're seeing how we can make further improvements in this, which is just EOG's way to do our business. So it's in place in the Eagle
componenttext: Evan, we've seen this work so well throughout all of our plays. We're under implementation currently. So it's in place and we're seeing how we can make further improvements in this, which is just EOG's way to do our business. So it's in place in the Eagle Ford and we're running it in the Permian Basin and also in the Rocky Mountains and most all of our plays. We're thrilled with the results and we're being able -- at first, our cost was a little bit higher and you'll notice that looking at the Eagle Ford, slightly higher. But we're finding ways to bring those costs down now.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could take another step at the completion question, specifically the high density completion in the Bakken. I think during David's prepared comments, he mentioned that, what I thought I heard was that, that was the first completion of the spot in the
componenttext: If I could take another step at the completion question, specifically the high density completion in the Bakken. I think during David's prepared comments, he mentioned that, what I thought I heard was that, that was the first completion of the spot in the Antelope Extension area. And I'm wondering if you could give us a little history, how long have you been doing this and in what areas you've been doing it in? And really, that's a remarkable results with the Riverview well and I'm wondering how applicable is that new completion technique across your whole footprint up there?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, that's correct. That was the first, what we consider high density completion in Antelope. And obviously, the results speak for themselves. It's an excellent well. And we've been like Gary mentioned, we're applying those t
componenttext: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, that's correct. That was the first, what we consider high density completion in Antelope. And obviously, the results speak for themselves. It's an excellent well. And we've been like Gary mentioned, we're applying those techniques really all across the company and certainly across the Bakken. No 2 wells are exactly the same. We always customize the completion job based on the. So we are implementing those tops techniques really there at Antelope and at the Bakken core. And obviously, we're doing that in the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin as well. But we're seeing a tremendous uplift in the productivity of the wells.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so in the core as well as the extension, the Antelope Extension?
componenttext: And so in the core as well as the extension, the Antelope Extension?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The completions aren't identical. Like I said, because the is throughout the area. But the key aspects of the completions will be implemented in the core and down the road and in the non-core as well.
componenttext: Yes. The completions aren't identical. Like I said, because the is throughout the area. But the key aspects of the completions will be implemented in the core and down the road and in the non-core as well.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then Bill, if I can try one more stab at this 2016 picture that obviously, everyone's curious about, but you guys are up still working on it. If know that you have this disciplined returns focus. I'm wondering if you could foresee, if the forward curv
componenttext: And then Bill, if I can try one more stab at this 2016 picture that obviously, everyone's curious about, but you guys are up still working on it. If know that you have this disciplined returns focus. I'm wondering if you could foresee, if the forward curve does bear out, is there a time in 2016 when you think you -- when you could foresee having progressing up on the efficiency and cost front that the returns will be sufficient that you'd want to go ahead and accelerate completion activity even if we're still looking at $52 oil at the end of '16?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Leo Mariani when RBC.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Leo Mariani when RBC.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping for a little bit more color around the staggered stack activity here in the Eagle Ford. Just trying to get a sense of what type of space between wellbores, you guys are imploring and basically, how long have you had some of these pilots on an
componenttext: I was hoping for a little bit more color around the staggered stack activity here in the Eagle Ford. Just trying to get a sense of what type of space between wellbores, you guys are imploring and basically, how long have you had some of these pilots on and when do you think we may see some results here?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms. For our staggered W patterns that we're testing now, we actually have several patterns across the field that we're testing as we speak. Just a reminder, in our last update on the Eagle Ford, we have about 3.2 billion barrels
componenttext: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms. For our staggered W patterns that we're testing now, we actually have several patterns across the field that we're testing as we speak. Just a reminder, in our last update on the Eagle Ford, we have about 3.2 billion barrels of recoverable oil out of 7,200 locations, that's an average of about 40-acre spacing. So obviously, we're testing spacing and these are W patterns in the lower Eagle Ford only. And so that spacing would be somewhat less than 40 acres. Each spacing pattern is slightly different and we are just beginning to see some of those early results and actually just testing, some of them haven't even come on production yet. So we still need some time to evaluate the production from these to understand what the impact is going to be to the field. Obviously, we're pretty optimistic based on some of the early results we've seen. But it's still early yet to really talk about the impact, so we're encouraged though.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess, I think a lot of people are -- just very curious on whether or not there's any decent kind of M&A or acreage acquisition opportunities out there in the market, giving low prices. Can you guys kind of address your thoughts on the curernt M&A m
componenttext: And I guess, I think a lot of people are -- just very curious on whether or not there's any decent kind of M&A or acreage acquisition opportunities out there in the market, giving low prices. Can you guys kind of address your thoughts on the curernt M&A market?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms again. Just like many of our peer companies, we're looking for those opportunities. I think you can see prices have been fairly good as far as people selling properties. I think they're-- the valuations are still pretty high.
componenttext: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms again. Just like many of our peer companies, we're looking for those opportunities. I think you can see prices have been fairly good as far as people selling properties. I think they're-- the valuations are still pretty high. You've seen very few large M&A structures out there and I think we're kind of seeing the same thing. We're -- we evaluated many things. I think what you'll probably see more of is the smaller tactical acquisitions, that's kind of what we're maybe more focused on than any kind of large M&A things out there. We are seeing opportunities in different basins and we are actively looking at things. We're still optimistic that there -- we're going to be able to do some smaller, small tactical acquisitions and build acreage positions in some of our key or emerging plays. We are having some success in just acquiring leasehold in some of our new emerging plays, more so than we have in the past, so that's positive. So overall, I think right now, the deals that are out there and available, there's still quite a bit of money chasing on, the prices are still pretty highly valued for the lowest properties. So the key is trying to find things for us, for EOG, the key is finding things that will add good valuable acreage that will compete with our existing inventory, that we're going to be very selective in what we chase.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015

componenttextpreview: No, other than just generally, the -- we don't guide by area and we're not going to be doing that in the future. But you can generally, the Eagle Ford is obviously, our strongest producer. The Bakken and the Permian are kind of second and third. But where
componenttext: No, other than just generally, the -- we don't guide by area and we're not going to be doing that in the future. But you can generally, the Eagle Ford is obviously, our strongest producer. The Bakken and the Permian are kind of second and third. But where our activity in the -- as you all know, in the Delaware Basin has doubled from last year. So we're growing volumes there very rapidly in the Permian.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe a segue as well as my first question on the Permian. I don't mean to be nit picky, but it seems like there was a relative shift the way the Leonard towards the Wolfcamp and the Delaware Basin. Has there been any change in the way you view the play,
componenttext: Maybe a segue as well as my first question on the Permian. I don't mean to be nit picky, but it seems like there was a relative shift the way the Leonard towards the Wolfcamp and the Delaware Basin. Has there been any change in the way you view the play, is this shift the Wolfcamp getting better? Then maybe just some overall commentary on your thoughts on the Delaware portfolio and potential for acceleration, going forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. This is Billy Helms. In the Delaware Basin, certainly we're excited about all 3 of the major plays we have there, the Wolfcamp, the Bone Springs and the Leonard. For the Leonard, it's a more mature play, for EOG. We've been operating there. We
componenttext: Yes, Brian. This is Billy Helms. In the Delaware Basin, certainly we're excited about all 3 of the major plays we have there, the Wolfcamp, the Bone Springs and the Leonard. For the Leonard, it's a more mature play, for EOG. We've been operating there. We have more history. We understand the play a little bit more than we do in some of the other place. So we've shifted some of that activity to the Wolfcamp and Bone Springs. The Bone Springs probably have the biggest relative increase in capital this year. We completed quite a few wells in the first half. And then the Wolfcamp, we'll be completing more wells in the second half of the year than we have in the first half. But in general, the Wolfcamp, we're still learning a lot about it. We've got quite a few target zones we're testing. We're testing various areas of the Wolfcamp play where we have acreage and we're testing some various spacing patterns. So we still have a lot to learn about the Wolfcamp. The other thing we're doing is with the Wolfcamp being in the deeper target, we're gathering additional data on the Leonard and Bone Springs pay zones when we drill down through, those on our way to the Wolfcamp. So by gathering additional petrophysical data and rock data, we're better able to look at the variability of the pay sections in those 2 shallower pay zones and gives us a better idea about how to develop those, how to better target those and where the best upside might be. So it's kind of an overall approach for you to understand the play better and that's one of the reasons we've -- major reason we've shifted more to the Wolfcamp.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just an overall question on portfolio, on the broader company portfolio. At this point, are -- we've had questions about the potential for acquisitions. But are there -- is there any interest on your end in divestitures? Our international a
componenttext: And then maybe just an overall question on portfolio, on the broader company portfolio. At this point, are -- we've had questions about the potential for acquisitions. But are there -- is there any interest on your end in divestitures? Our international assets still considered core at this point? Or are there any other parts of the portfolio when you think about long-term portfolio optimization, where you can be a potential seller?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ryan, yes. We're always interested in upgrading our portfolio. And so every year, we mix in property sales in our plan and this year, it's no different. 2016 will be no different. And we want to continue to divest the -- think about divesting the properti
componenttext: Ryan, yes. We're always interested in upgrading our portfolio. And so every year, we mix in property sales in our plan and this year, it's no different. 2016 will be no different. And we want to continue to divest the -- think about divesting the properties that are less profitable, obviously, that don't fit our CapEx requirements. We have such an enormous high graded inventory to develop. We're always wanting to evaluate the potential of our existing properties. At this point in the company, we don't really have a lot of what I would call crummy properties or not quality properties. All of our properties are fairly quality, but we're going to be looking at continuing to upgrade our portfolio as we go forward.

Are you saying that you think that the current strip, that EOG can keep exit rate '15 productions flat next year, within cash flow?

componenttext: I think that's an accurate statement, Pearce. We're set up so well with the DUC inventory that even with the low prices, we would have enough cash flow to keep production flat.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is you had a good new slide in your deck about compensation factor weightings for the E&P industry. And EOG had much less emphasis on production and reserve growth than the tiers. And I assume obviously, that feeds into your decision
componenttext: And then my follow-up is you had a good new slide in your deck about compensation factor weightings for the E&P industry. And EOG had much less emphasis on production and reserve growth than the tiers. And I assume obviously, that feeds into your decision to build the DUC inventory in the second half of this year higher than what you originally thought, and be restrained in production because of the lower price environment that we're in. However, earlier on the call, you stated that you would not have '16 production decline year-over-year at the current strip. And so if the returns for '16 aren't that great, and your compensation structure doesn't tell you to push production, why would you employ the same strategy in '16 as you're employing in the second half of this year? Or is there a mechanical reason why you don't want production to decline? Is it problematic? Or is it just strictly cash flow needs?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think next year, Pearce, what we're saying is that even with the minimum -- even with the low price cash flow scenario, the highest return investment we could make in the company would be to begin completing those DUCs and complete those DUCs earli
componenttext: Yes. I think next year, Pearce, what we're saying is that even with the minimum -- even with the low price cash flow scenario, the highest return investment we could make in the company would be to begin completing those DUCs and complete those DUCs earlier in the year versus spending that money on other things. So the quality of these DUCs is very high-quality. So, and we have infrastructure in place. So that would be the highest return place to put the money.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I specifically would like to ask you a question in the North of Delaware Basin. I'm noticing that these wells are really very, very attractively priced, like $7 million DUC. So question is, is it less overpressure? How many strings of casing do you use ou
componenttext: I specifically would like to ask you a question in the North of Delaware Basin. I'm noticing that these wells are really very, very attractively priced, like $7 million DUC. So question is, is it less overpressure? How many strings of casing do you use out there? Also, this close we're looking at, are they in patch sort of best drilling or pad mode? Could we expect some more reduction to come in? Probably alluding to something you said earlier, and the final development scheme, would you be stacking these really prolific zones together when you go into manufacturing mode? That's probably something different from Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hello, Irene. This is Gary Thomas. Yes, we're really pleased with the progress that we've made there in the Delaware. But I would say it's really early on, and you really -- that was really good comment there as far as yes, it is over pressured and we're
componenttext: Hello, Irene. This is Gary Thomas. Yes, we're really pleased with the progress that we've made there in the Delaware. But I would say it's really early on, and you really -- that was really good comment there as far as yes, it is over pressured and we're still working on our wellbore geometry. So we've tested several different things. We believe that we'll be able to get to a point where we're looking at a 2-stringed design and just like we always do, and like you've seen us do in the Eagle Ford and in the Bakken, we'll just continue to reduce those days and we'll reduce those costs. I was just going to say yes, you'll look through those various plays and we'll reduce our days from anywhere from 15% to 30% and of course, that translates to costs. We're really making a lot of progress on the completion side and cost of production. So yes, overall, our total well cost has been reduced by about 20%. But again, it's less than the Delaware and we're just kind of turning that on.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I was wondering, for these, are the 2 wells you quoted, they're really short lateral and the custom, you've really got some impressive grades. And so my question for you, are you targeting pure shale? Are you looking for something a little different?
componenttext: So I was wondering, for these, are the 2 wells you quoted, they're really short lateral and the custom, you've really got some impressive grades. And so my question for you, are you targeting pure shale? Are you looking for something a little different?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the Wolfcamp is -- I'd say it's -- we're looking at whatever the best pay target is in those, at this point in time. So in every one of these plays, as Bill mentioned earlier, we're spending a lot of time on targeting, trying to understand what the
componenttext: Well, the Wolfcamp is -- I'd say it's -- we're looking at whatever the best pay target is in those, at this point in time. So in every one of these plays, as Bill mentioned earlier, we're spending a lot of time on targeting, trying to understand what the best part of that rock is. If it's a shale, that's great. If it's not, if it's a silk stone, we look at those. So each area, the target varies and so we spent quite a bit of time trying to understand what is the best target and then how do we best develop that, and the completion approach varies on each one of those, and the spacing approach might vary on each one of those. And in general, our target windows are getting much more narrow than they had been in the past and we're seeing that by keeping the wellbores in the best rock longer and being able to more intensely complete those wells in that best target, productivity is better and the declines are lower.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is on LOE costs. We saw a nice decline in this quarter and the guidance suggests that the run rate should be in the low $6 range or so, which is also down from all of last year. We've seen most of the company's report lower LOE cost as w
componenttext: My first question is on LOE costs. We saw a nice decline in this quarter and the guidance suggests that the run rate should be in the low $6 range or so, which is also down from all of last year. We've seen most of the company's report lower LOE cost as well. I'm just trying to gauge how sustainable the lower trend is for you guys. It looks like the decline for EOG was less a function of fewer workovers, but rather a significant decline on the O&M front. You've reference the impact of new infrastructure in the core to low. But can you maybe talk about which components of O&M you're seeing cost declines and then how much of those savings are secular versus cyclical?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Phillips. This is Gary Thomas. I'm sure you noticed too that yes, first quarter and we commented on that last earnings call, it was above our guidance. And our reason is we were a little bit late getting some of our infrastructure installed and that
componenttext: Yes, Phillips. This is Gary Thomas. I'm sure you noticed too that yes, first quarter and we commented on that last earnings call, it was above our guidance. And our reason is we were a little bit late getting some of our infrastructure installed and that all did come on, so we had that infrastructure in place in our major plays. A few other things yet to be done there, so as far as driving our cost down the way we have here in the second quarter, it's about half [ph] through having infrastructure, maybe 1/4 of that just cost reduction and other 1/4 would be just efficiency gains. So a large portion of that would be sustainable. It's just really -- we always make comments about our infrastructure and that spending. But it sure has been official for us getting our cost down and you'll notice that our chart at #12 there, we're really pleased with us becoming more of a liquids company and then being able to maintain our lifting costs fairly flat. And the second...

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I did have a couple of final remarks. So first of all, just thank you for the great questions. I also want to thank all the employees of EOG for their tremendous efforts and contributions this year in making EOG successful. You've just done an outsta
componenttext: Yes. I did have a couple of final remarks. So first of all, just thank you for the great questions. I also want to thank all the employees of EOG for their tremendous efforts and contributions this year in making EOG successful. You've just done an outstanding job. My final message is this. And I think you've heard it all through the call. The company is -- continues to be focused on creating long-term shareholder value and we're not chasing short-term volumes in an oversupply of oil market. We're really focused on the fundamentals, improving returns, improving operating margins and building decades of higher return growth potential. So our plan, EOG's plan is to deliver value to shareholders with high margin, high return production growth for years to come. So I just want to thank everybody for listening and certainly, thank you for your support.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call.As a reminder, this call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chief Financ
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call.
As a reminder, this call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing second quarter 2015 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-lo
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing second quarter 2015 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-looking statements have been outlined in the earnings release and EOG's SEC filings, and we incorporate those by reference for this call. This conference call also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation schedules for these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures can be found on our website at www.eogresources.com. The SEC permits oil and gas companies in their filings with the SEC to disclose not only proved reserves, but also probable reserves as well as possible reserves. Some of the reserve estimates on this conference call and webcast may include potential reserves or other estimated reserves not necessarily calculated in accordance with or contemplated by the SEC's reserve reporting guidelines. We incorporate by reference the cautionary note to U.S. investors that appears at the bottom of our press release.
Participating on the call this morning are Bill Thomas, Chairman and CEO; Gary Thomas, President and Chief Operating Officer; Billy Helms, EVP, Exploration and Production; David Trice, EVP, Exploration and Production; Lance Terveen, VP, Marketing Operations; and Cedric Burgher, Senior VP, Investor and Public Relations.
An updated IR presentation was posted to our website yesterday evening, and we included guidance for the third quarter and full year 2015 in yesterday's press release. This morning, we'll discuss topics in the following order: Bill Thomas will update our 2015 plan; David Trice and Billy Helms will review operational results; I will then discuss EOG's financials, capital structure and hedge position; and Bill will provide concluding remarks. Here's Bill Thomas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. We're pleased with the performance from our spacing tests using our integrated completion process in the Bakken. We now estimate that our Bakken and Three Forks total net resource potential is just over 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent. T
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. We're pleased with the performance from our spacing tests using our integrated completion process in the Bakken. We now estimate that our Bakken and Three Forks total net resource potential is just over 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent. That's almost 2.5x our original estimate of 420 million barrels of oil equivalent. Remaining drilling inventory increased from 580 to over 1,500 net drilling locations. This represents 760 million barrels of oil equivalent that have remaining net potential reserves and decades of drilling in this premier North Dakota asset. 
In addition to the updated resource estimates, we split the Bakken into 2 categories that we have titled core acreage and noncore acreage. The core produces returns that are competitive with both the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin, and includes our acreage in the Bakken core and Antelope Extension. Noncore represents acreage in the Bakken Lite, State Line and Elm Coulee areas. Although our main focus will be in the core area, we believe that with modern high-density completions and current well costs, the noncore acreage will be very economic even with low oil prices. 
We defined 120,000 net acres and 590 net drilling locations in the core, which represents remaining net resource potential of 360 million barrels of oil equivalent. This inventory alone offers over 10 years of drilling. Noncore acreage represents remaining net resource potential of 400 million barrels equivalent. In this acreage, we defined 110,000 net acres and 950 net drilling locations, which provide decades of inventory. Our wells in the Bakken continue to exceed expectations. A great example of the progress we're making is the Riverview 102-32H well. This is the first Bakken well in the Antelope Extension we have drilled using a high-density completion. The well came on online with a maximum rate of 3,395 barrels of oil per day and 6 million cubic feet of rich natural gas, with an average rate of 2,760 barrels of oil per day for July, this short 4,300-foot lateral will be the highest-rate oil well ever recorded for the Bakken or Three Forks. We are excited to continue applying high-density completions throughout the entire play as we move forward. 
In addition to improve returns to advance completions, we've made tremendous progress on Bakken completed well costs, which are now $7.1 million for an 8,400-foot treated lateral. This is almost 20% decrease in well costs from 2014. Most of the well cost savings are due to efficiency gains rather than vendor cost reductions and therefore, should be sustainable over time. Drilling times are now averaging 8.2 days spud to TD for an 8,400-foot lateral with our best being a record 5.6 days. We are also realizing significant completion efficiencies. Currently, we are averaging more than 10 completion stages per day, up from 4 to 5 stages per day in 2014. In addition, plug drill-out times have been cut in half since 2014. 
Finally, cost savings are not just limited to CapEx. We added infrastructure this year in the Bakken core and as a result, we have seen dramatic LOE reductions. Second quarter LOE is down more than 25% from the first quarter. The increase to our Bakken reserve potential and drilling inventory illustrates the value of EOG's exploration and technology leadership. We interplay as the first mover and capture the best assets, then we grow them to the drill bit and improve recoveries over time with drilling and completion technology developed in-house. This is how EOG continues to grow organically. 
Here's Billy Helms to update you on the Delaware Basin and the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. The plays in the Delaware Basin are also proving to be very good examples of how EOG is repositioning itself to generate strong returns in this period of low commodity prices. We have made improvements to productivity while significantly lo
componenttext:
Thanks, David. The plays in the Delaware Basin are also proving to be very good examples of how EOG is repositioning itself to generate strong returns in this period of low commodity prices. We have made improvements to productivity while significantly lowering completed well cost. In the case of improved productivity, we are finding that wellbore targeting, along with our integrated completion approach, continues to provide upside on well performance. 
In the second quarter, we maintained our activity in the Second Bone Spring Sand, testing various spacing patterns and targets. Two recent wells, the Dragon 36 State #501H and 502H were completed in a 1,000-foot space pattern with initial production rates of 1,075 and 1,755 barrels of oil per day. Another recent completion in Lea County, New Mexico, the Frazier 34 State Com #501H tested 1,705 barrels of oil per day with 145 barrels per day of NGLs and 1.1 million cubic feet per day of natural gas. 
The completed well costs for the Second Bone Spring Sand are currently averaging $6 million per well, representing a 22% reduction from last year's average. A major portion of the cost savings can be attributed to sustainable efficiency improvements in both drilling and completion operations rather than solely vendor cost reductions. Improved well performance, coupled with lower well cost, make this play very attractive in this low commodity price environment. We will continue evaluating well performance to determine the proper spacing and ultimate recovery. 
During the last quarter, we also completed several strong Wolfcamp wells in the overpressured, oil window of the play. Two recent completions in Lea County, New Mexico, the Dragon 36 State #701H and the Hearns 27 State Com #703H had initial production rates per well of 2,650 barrels of oil per day along with 285 barrels per day of NGLs and 1.9 million cubic feet per day of natural gas. As we evaluate various targets and spacing patterns, this play promises to be a high-return growth asset for EOG. 
Similar advancements have been achieved in the Leonard play. A typical well now costs $5.5 million and we are testing spacing patterns of 300 feet and 500 feet between wells. One recent completion in Lea County, New Mexico, the Gem 36 State Com #1H had an initial production rate of 2,200 barrels of oil per day, 460 barrels per day of NGLs and 2.6 million cubic feet per day of natural gas. Our downspacing efforts demonstrate that we can drill wells closer together without sacrificing production. These new completion designs are allowing us to improve the overall economics and ultimate recovery. 
Due to these strong results, we anticipate the Delaware Basin will play a significant role in EOG's long-term growth. As typical with our other plays, EOG is -- will evaluate options and invest in the infrastructure needed to serve future production growth while keeping our long-term operating costs to a minimum. We are very excited about the opportunities and growth potential for EOG's Delaware Basin properties. 
Now moving to the Eagle Ford, which continues to be our workhorse asset. Due to the sheer scale of our operations there, it functions as a laboratory for technical progress, on target selection, geosteering and high-density completion designs. To support our wellbore targeting efforts this year, we drilled 4 pilot wells to gather additional log data and provide a more complete picture of our acreage. This information greatly enhances our understanding of any specific target's variability across the play. We are currently conducting test using a staggered W pattern in the lower Eagle Ford, and the new data we've gathered on the targets is encouraging, as it supports our expectations for success. 
While it's too early to share results, we are excited about the benefits our targeting efforts can have on our Eagle Ford drilling program and ultimate field recovery. We are also pleased with the progress of cost-reduction efforts in the Eagle Ford. Our average completed well cost is currently $5.5 million and headed toward our 2015 goal of $5.3 million. Similar to our other plays, most of these cost reductions are being achieved through efficiency gains and should be sustainable. Also, the productivity of the wells continues to show steady improvement through our emphasis on targeting and high-density completions. Some of the recent wells are highlighted in our press release. The combination of cost reductions and better well performance, through the application of technology, is ensuring that this world-class asset will continue to deliver stronger growth for years to come. 
I'll now turn it over to Tim Driggers to discuss financials and capital structure

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Billy. Capitalized interest for the second quarter 2015 was $11 million. Total cash exploration and development expenditures were $1.2 billion, excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering system
componenttext:
Thanks, Billy. Capitalized interest for the second quarter 2015 was $11 million. Total cash exploration and development expenditures were $1.2 billion, excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $85 million. 
At the end of June 2015, total debt outstanding was $6.4 billion and the debt to total capitalization ratio was 27%. At June 30, we had $1.4 billion of cash on hand, giving us non-GAAP net debt of $5 billion for a net debt-to-total capital ratio of 22%. In April, Moody's confirmed EOG's A3 rating with a stable outlook. In July, we successfully entered into a new $2 billion credit agreement to replace the existing one, which would've matured in October 2016. Terms of the new agreement were similar to the prior credit agreement. 
The effective tax rate for the second quarter was 146%, and current tax expense was $41 million. For the period August 1 through December 31, 2015, EOG has crude oil financial price swaps contracts in place for 10,000 barrels of oil per day at a weighted average price of $89.98 per barrel. For the second -- I'm sorry, for the period September 1 through December 31, 2015, EOG has natural gas financial price swap contracts in place for 175,000 MMBtu per day at a weighted average price of $4.51 per MMBtu. These numbers exclude options that are exercisable by our counterparties. 
Now I'll turn it back over to Bill.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, I wanted to start with a macro question if I may, because you guys have obviously, done a phenomenal job of getting your cost down, your efficiency improvements, and I think a couple displays really speak to the depth of the portfolio. But it seems
componenttext: Bill, I wanted to start with a macro question if I may, because you guys have obviously, done a phenomenal job of getting your cost down, your efficiency improvements, and I think a couple displays really speak to the depth of the portfolio. But it seems that you're making a macro decision based on oil price here and no one else seems to be taking the same view. In other words, you're foregoing production growth, and a lot of your peers with lesser economics are continuing to pursue drills. So I'm just kind of wondering if you can help us reconcile your macro thoughts with the stock-specific opportunities you have in the portfolio, and I guess with a view to 2016. And I I've got a follow-up, please.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. Our macro view is we think, a pretty solid view. We do a lot of work and a lot of study on the process and we particularly model what everybody is saying in the U.S. and what they're going to be doing in the second half of this year through the
componenttext: Yes, Doug. Our macro view is we think, a pretty solid view. We do a lot of work and a lot of study on the process and we particularly model what everybody is saying in the U.S. and what they're going to be doing in the second half of this year through their guidance. And we really believe that in the second part of this year, we're going to see some strong month-over-month decline rates. And it may take -- it will take probably at least 2 or 3 more months for the monthly numbers to confirm this. There's a 2-month lag in the data. And the data does not -- as we know, not precise and it gets updated over time. So what we really need to see to confirm this is the July and August monthly data. And that'll come in, in September and October. So hopefully by that time, the declines will be a bit more evident to everybody. And if that happens, we could see a bit more firmness in the price. So our model shows, by what everybody is guiding, that the U.S. will grow about 500,000 to 600,000 barrels a day this year versus the 1.2 million barrels a day, last year, so there's a significant drop off in the year-over-year growth rate. And then if the -- if prices continue to stay low through the end of the year, we expect 2016 to have continued month-over-month decline rates in the U.S. and that will be joined by decline rates in other non-OPEC supply in 2016. And the combination of those things with the continued reasonable demand growth gives a decent opportunity for prices to be a bit better than they are right now in 2016. So certainly, that was a factor in our decision to defer spending capital, trying to accelerate oil in the current market. The other thing is certainly is that we just can't see a good business reason to outspend growing oil in an oversupplied oil market. That does not make sense to us, so we believe we made the right decision.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, I admire the discipline. I don't want to belabor this point, but I guess what I'm thinking is if I look at Slide 5, you got a -- you clearly have better returns today, for example, in the Leonard than you did when oil was substantially higher, which
componenttext: Bill, I admire the discipline. I don't want to belabor this point, but I guess what I'm thinking is if I look at Slide 5, you got a -- you clearly have better returns today, for example, in the Leonard than you did when oil was substantially higher, which obviously fits your incentive structure to attract returns. I guess, what I'm really kind of thinking is if, let's assume that you're wrong and oil prices don't recover because consensus seems to be lower for longer, would you go back to growth in 2016?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me follow up on your 2016 comments and I appreciate your asset position and the budget you have today. Philosophically, I mean, if it's necessary to stay within cash flow into 2016, are you willing to go into annual production declines? Or is that whe
componenttext: Let me follow up on your 2016 comments and I appreciate your asset position and the budget you have today. Philosophically, I mean, if it's necessary to stay within cash flow into 2016, are you willing to go into annual production declines? Or is that where you would consider drawing DUCs or moving to an outspend?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: The question there, Evan, is yes, would we just grow production. We're not inclined to grow production just in a continued low price environment, but like Bill is saying, we're very well positioned with all of our high-quality DUCs, wells not completed. A
componenttext: The question there, Evan, is yes, would we just grow production. We're not inclined to grow production just in a continued low price environment, but like Bill is saying, we're very well positioned with all of our high-quality DUCs, wells not completed. And we're going to end the year with 15 to 18 drilling rigs, and we'll only have 13 under long contract next year. So in order to go ahead and just to at least maintain, possibly grow production, depending on what the prices are, we'll start with quite a number of completion units and that just -- that allows us to bring production on rapidly and also we'll be able to do it at low cost with all the reduced costs we've had from just increased efficiencies here through 2015.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. My second one, if I could, on the high-density completions. I mean, you guys are clearly the leader here. It's 95% Eagle Ford wells this year, you've begun in the Bakken with now a very strong handle on extension well, implement the Second Bone Spr
componenttext: Great. My second one, if I could, on the high-density completions. I mean, you guys are clearly the leader here. It's 95% Eagle Ford wells this year, you've begun in the Bakken with now a very strong handle on extension well, implement the Second Bone Springs, with this quarter, last quarter, Wolfcamp, and the 3Q [ph] in Leonard, since the beginning of the year. I mean, can you walk me through how long it takes you to substantially implement those designs across your Delaware and Bakken positions? I'm just wondering how we should think about how long it takes to get to a similar percentage of high-density completions as you have in the Eagle Ford and the rest of your portfolio?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Evan, we've seen this work so well throughout all of our plays. We're under implementation currently. So it's in place, and we're seeing how we can make further improvements in this, which is just EOG's way to do our business. So it's in place in the Eagl
componenttext: Evan, we've seen this work so well throughout all of our plays. We're under implementation currently. So it's in place, and we're seeing how we can make further improvements in this, which is just EOG's way to do our business. So it's in place in the Eagle Ford, and we're running it in the Permian Basin and also in the Rocky Mountains and most all of our plays. We're thrilled with the results and we're being able -- at first, our cost was a little bit higher, and you'll notice that looking at the Eagle Ford, slightly higher. But we're finding ways to bring those costs down now.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could take another stab at that completion question, specifically the high-density completion in the Bakken. I think during David's prepared comments, he mentioned that, what I thought I heard was that the -- that was the first completion of the stac
componenttext: If I could take another stab at that completion question, specifically the high-density completion in the Bakken. I think during David's prepared comments, he mentioned that, what I thought I heard was that the -- that was the first completion of the stack in the Antelope Extension area. And I'm wondering if you could give us a little history, how long have you been doing this and in what areas you've been doing it in? And really, that's a remarkable results with the Riverview well, and I'm wondering how applicable is that new completion technique across your whole footprint up there?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, that's correct. That was the first, what we have considered high-density completion in Antelope. And obviously, the results speak for themselves. It's an excellent well. And we've been, like Gary mentioned, we're applying
componenttext: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, that's correct. That was the first, what we have considered high-density completion in Antelope. And obviously, the results speak for themselves. It's an excellent well. And we've been, like Gary mentioned, we're applying those techniques really all across the company and certainly across the Bakken. No 2 wells are exactly the same. We always customize the completion job based on the geology. So we are implementing those tops techniques really there at Antelope and in the Bakken core. And obviously, we're doing that in the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin as well. But we're seeing a tremendous uplift in the productivity of the wells.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And so in the core as well as the extension, the Antelope Extension?
componenttext: Got it. And so in the core as well as the extension, the Antelope Extension?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the completions aren't identical, like I said, because the geology varies throughout the area. But the key aspects of the completions will be implemented in the core and down the road and in the noncore as well.
componenttext: Yes, the completions aren't identical, like I said, because the geology varies throughout the area. But the key aspects of the completions will be implemented in the core and down the road and in the noncore as well.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, Bill, if I could try one more stab at this 2016 picture that obviously, everyone's curious about that you guys are up -- still working on it. I knew that you have this disciplined returns focus. I'm wondering if you could foresee, if the
componenttext: Got it. And then, Bill, if I could try one more stab at this 2016 picture that obviously, everyone's curious about that you guys are up -- still working on it. I knew that you have this disciplined returns focus. I'm wondering if you could foresee, if the forward curve does bear out, is there a time in 2016 when you think you've -- when you could foresee having progress enough on the efficiency and cost front that the returns will be sufficient that you'd want to go ahead and accelerate completion activity even if we're still looking at $52 oil at the end of '16?

componenttext: I was hoping for a little bit more color around the staggered stack activity here in the Eagle Ford. Just trying to get a sense of what type of space between wellbores you guys are imploring and basically, how long have you had some of these pilots on and when do you think we may see results here?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms. For our staggered W patterns that we're testing now, we actually have several patterns across the field that we're testing as we speak. Just a reminder, in our last update on the Eagle Ford, we have about 3.2 billion barrels
componenttext: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms. For our staggered W patterns that we're testing now, we actually have several patterns across the field that we're testing as we speak. Just a reminder, in our last update on the Eagle Ford, we have about 3.2 billion barrels of recoverable oil out of 7,200 locations. That's an average of about 40-acre spacing. So obviously, we're testing spacing and these are W patterns in the lower Eagle Ford only. And so that spacing would be somewhat less than 40 acres. Each spacing pattern is slightly different and we are just beginning to see some of those early results and actually just testing, some of them haven't even come on production yet. So we still need some time to evaluate the production from these to understand what the impact is going to be to the field. Obviously, we're pretty optimistic based on some of the early results we've seen. But it's still early yet to really talk about the impact, so we're encouraged though.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, I think a lot of people are -- just very curious about whether or not there's any decent kind of M&A or acreage acquisition opportunities out there in the market, giving low prices. Can you guys kind of address your thou
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, I think a lot of people are -- just very curious about whether or not there's any decent kind of M&A or acreage acquisition opportunities out there in the market, giving low prices. Can you guys kind of address your thoughts on the current M&A market?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms again. Just like many of our peer companies, we're looking for those opportunities. I think you can see prices have been fairly good as far as people selling properties. I think they're -- the valuation's just still pretty hi
componenttext: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms again. Just like many of our peer companies, we're looking for those opportunities. I think you can see prices have been fairly good as far as people selling properties. I think they're -- the valuation's just still pretty high. You've seen very few large M&A structures out there, and I think we're kind of seeing the same thing. We're -- we've evaluated many things. I think what you'll probably see more of is the smaller tactical acquisitions, that's kind of what we're maybe more focused on than any kind of large M&A things out there. We are seeing opportunities in different basins, and we are actively looking at things. We're still optimistic that there -- we're going to be able to do some smaller -- small tactical acquisitions and build acreage positions in some of our key or emerging plays. We are having some success in just acquiring leasehold in some of our new emerging plays, more so than we have in the past, so that's positive. So overall, I think right now, the deals that are out there and available, there's still quite a bit of money chasing on -- the prices are still pretty highly valued for the lowest properties. So the key is trying to find things for us, for EOG, the key is finding things that will add good valuable acreage that will compete with our existing inventory, that we're going to be very selective in what we chase.
