headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've maintained our production as far as domestic, just flat here and that's kind of what we guide here through 2015, so that's probably likely for '16.
componenttext: We've maintained our production as far as domestic, just flat here and that's kind of what we guide here through 2015, so that's probably likely for '16.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. My second one, if I could, on the high-density completions. I mean, you guys are clearly the leader here. It's 95% Eagle Ford wells this year, you've begun in the Bakken with a very strong Antelope extension well, implemented the Second Bone Spring
componenttext: Great. My second one, if I could, on the high-density completions. I mean, you guys are clearly the leader here. It's 95% Eagle Ford wells this year, you've begun in the Bakken with a very strong Antelope extension well, implemented the Second Bone Springs, with this quarter or last quarter, Wolfcamp, and the 3Q [ph] in Leonard, since the beginning of the year. I mean, can you walk me through how long it takes you to substantially implement those designs across your Delaware and Bakken positions? I'm just wondering how we should think about how long it takes to get to a similar percentage of high-density completions as you have in the Eagle Ford and the rest of your portfolio?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Evan, we've seen this work so well throughout all of our plays. We're under implementation currently. So it's in place, and we're seeing how we can make further improvements in this, which is just EOG's way to do our business. So it's in place in the Eagl
componenttext: Evan, we've seen this work so well throughout all of our plays. We're under implementation currently. So it's in place, and we're seeing how we can make further improvements in this, which is just EOG's way to do our business. So it's in place in the Eagle Ford, and we're running it in the Permian Basin and also in the Rocky Mountains and most all of our plays. We're thrilled with the results and we're being able -- at first, our cost was a little bit higher, and you'll notice that looking at the Eagle Ford, slightly higher. But we're finding ways to bring those costs down now.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could take another stab at that completion question, specifically the high-density and anti-density completion in the Bakken. I think during David's prepared comments, he mentioned that, what I thought I heard was that the -- that was the first compl
componenttext: If I could take another stab at that completion question, specifically the high-density and anti-density completion in the Bakken. I think during David's prepared comments, he mentioned that, what I thought I heard was that the -- that was the first completion of the stack in the Antelope Extension area. And I'm wondering if you could give us a little history, how long have you been doing this and in what areas you've been doing it in? And really, that's a remarkable result with the Riverview well, and I'm wondering how applicable is that new completion technique across your whole footprint up there?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, that's correct. That was the first, what we have considered high-density completion in Antelope. And obviously, the results speak for themselves. It's an excellent well. And we've been, like Gary mentioned, we're applying
componenttext: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, that's correct. That was the first, what we have considered high-density completion in Antelope. And obviously, the results speak for themselves. It's an excellent well. And we've been, like Gary mentioned, we're applying those techniques really all across the company and certainly across the Bakken. No 2 wells are exactly the same. We always customize the completion job based on the geology. So we are implementing those tops techniques really there at Antelope and in the Bakken core. And obviously, we're doing that in the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin as well. But we're seeing a tremendous uplift in the productivity of the wells.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And so in the core as well as the extension, Antelope Extension?
componenttext: Got it. And so in the core as well as the extension, Antelope Extension?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the completions aren't identical, like I said, because the geology varies throughout the area. But the key aspects of the completions will be implemented in the core and on down the road and in the noncore as well.
componenttext: Yes, the completions aren't identical, like I said, because the geology varies throughout the area. But the key aspects of the completions will be implemented in the core and on down the road and in the noncore as well.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, Bill, if I could try one more stab at this 2016 picture that obviously, everyone's curious about but you guys are up -- still working on it. I knew that you have this disciplined returns focus. I'm wondering if you could foresee, if the
componenttext: Got it. And then, Bill, if I could try one more stab at this 2016 picture that obviously, everyone's curious about but you guys are up -- still working on it. I knew that you have this disciplined returns focus. I'm wondering if you could foresee, if the forward curve does bear out, is there a time in 2016 when you think you've -- when you could foresee having progressed enough on the efficiency and cost front that the returns would be sufficient that you'd want to go ahead and accelerate completion activity even if we're still looking at $52 oil at the end of '16?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Leo Mariani with RBC.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Leo Mariani with RBC.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping for a little bit more color around the staggered stack activity here in the Eagle Ford. Just trying to get a sense of what type of space between wellbores you guys are imploring and basically, how long have you had some of these pilots on and
componenttext: I was hoping for a little bit more color around the staggered stack activity here in the Eagle Ford. Just trying to get a sense of what type of space between wellbores you guys are imploring and basically, how long have you had some of these pilots on and when do you think we may see results here?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms. For our staggered W patterns that we're testing now, we actually have several patterns across the field that we're testing as we speak. Just a reminder, in our last update on the Eagle Ford, we have about 3.2 billion barrels
componenttext: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms. For our staggered W patterns that we're testing now, we actually have several patterns across the field that we're testing as we speak. Just a reminder, in our last update on the Eagle Ford, we have about 3.2 billion barrels of recoverable oil out of 7,200 locations. That's an average of about 40-acre spacing. So obviously, we're testing spacing and these are W patterns in the lower Eagle Ford only. And so that spacing would be somewhat less than 40 acres. Each spacing pattern is slightly different and we are just beginning to see some of those early results and actually just testing, some of them haven't even come on production yet. So we still need some time to evaluate the production from these to understand what the impact is going to be to the field. Obviously, we're pretty optimistic based on some of the early results we've seen. But it's still early yet to really talk about the impact, so we're encouraged though.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, I think a lot of people are just very curious about whether or not there's any decent kind of M&A or acreage acquisition opportunities out there in the market, given low prices. Can you guys kind of address your thoughts
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, I think a lot of people are just very curious about whether or not there's any decent kind of M&A or acreage acquisition opportunities out there in the market, given low prices. Can you guys kind of address your thoughts on the current M&A market?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms again. Just like many of our peer companies, we're looking for those opportunities. I think you can see prices have been fairly good as far as people selling properties. I think they're -- the valuations are still pretty high
componenttext: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms again. Just like many of our peer companies, we're looking for those opportunities. I think you can see prices have been fairly good as far as people selling properties. I think they're -- the valuations are still pretty high. You've seen very few large M&A structures out there, and I think we're kind of seeing the same thing. We're -- we've evaluated many things. I think what you'll probably see more of is the smaller tactical acquisitions, that's kind of what we're maybe more focused on than any kind of large M&A things out there. We are seeing opportunities in different basins, and we are actively looking at things. We're still optimistic that there -- we're going to be able to do some more small tactical acquisitions and build acreage positions in some of our key or emerging plays. We are having some success in just acquiring leasehold in some of our new emerging plays, more so than we have in the past, so that's positive. So overall, I think right now, the deals that are out there and available, there's still quite a bit of money chasing them. The prices are still pretty highly valued for those properties. So the key is trying to find things for us, for EOG, the key is finding things that will add good valuable acreage that will compete with our existing inventory, but we're going to be very selective in what we chase.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Subash Chandra with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Subash Chandra with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: From your comment earlier that your base decline rate is you're making progress there, et cetera. So is it fair to conclude then that you're pretty well convinced the combination of lateral targeting and high-density completion is enhancing EUR recovery v
componenttext: From your comment earlier that your base decline rate is you're making progress there, et cetera. So is it fair to conclude then that you're pretty well convinced the combination of lateral targeting and high-density completion is enhancing EUR recovery versus accelerated recovery of existing reserves? And that the decline curve does not change on these completions versus the base completions? And then I had a follow-up.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up, it's something you've hesitated to answer before, I'll try it again anyway. But is there any regional color you can give on production by basin in your guide? Which areas might be rising and falling, et cetera?
componenttext: And my follow-up, it's something you've hesitated to answer before, I'll try it again anyway. But is there any regional color you can give on production by basin in your guide? Which areas might be rising and falling, et cetera?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, other than just generally, the -- we don't guide by area and we're not going to be doing that in the future. But you can generally, the Eagle Ford is obviously, our strongest producer. The Bakken and the Permian are kind of second and third. And -- bu
componenttext: No, other than just generally, the -- we don't guide by area and we're not going to be doing that in the future. But you can generally, the Eagle Ford is obviously, our strongest producer. The Bakken and the Permian are kind of second and third. And -- but where our activity in the -- as you all know, in the Delaware Basin this year has doubled from last year. So we're growing volumes there rather rapidly in the Permian.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe a segue as well into my first question on the Permian. I don't mean to be nitpicky, but it seemed like there was a relative shift away from the Leonard and towards the Wolfcamp and the Delaware Basin. Has there been any change in the way you view th
componenttext: Maybe a segue as well into my first question on the Permian. I don't mean to be nitpicky, but it seemed like there was a relative shift away from the Leonard and towards the Wolfcamp and the Delaware Basin. Has there been any change in the way you view the play? Is this shift to Wolfcamp getting better? Then maybe just some overall commentary on your thoughts on the Delaware portfolio and potential for acceleration going forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ryan. This is Billy Helms. In the Delaware Basin, certainly we're excited about all 3 of the major plays we have there, the Wolfcamp, the Bone Springs and the Leonard. For the Leonard, it's a more mature play, for EOG. We've been operating there. We
componenttext: Yes, Ryan. This is Billy Helms. In the Delaware Basin, certainly we're excited about all 3 of the major plays we have there, the Wolfcamp, the Bone Springs and the Leonard. For the Leonard, it's a more mature play, for EOG. We've been operating there. We have more history. We understand the play a little bit more than we do some of the other plays. So we've shifted some of that activity to the Wolfcamp and Bone Springs. The Bone Springs probably has the biggest relative increase in capital this year. We completed quite a few wells in the first half. And then the Wolfcamp, we'll be completing more wells in the second half of the year than we have in the first half. But in general, the Wolfcamp, we're still learning a lot about it. We've got quite a few target zones we're testing. We're testing various areas of the Wolfcamp play where we have acreage, and we're testing some various spacing patterns. So we still have a lot to learn about the Wolfcamp. And the other thing we're doing is with the Wolfcamp being in the deeper target, we're gathering additional data on the Leonard and Bone Springs pay zones when we drill down through those on our way to the Wolfcamp. So by gathering additional petrophysical data and rock data, we're better able to look at the variability of the pay sections in those 2 shallower pay zones and gives us a better idea about how to develop those, how to better target those and where the best upside might be. So it's kind of an overall approach to understand the play better, and that's one of the reasons we've -- a major reason we've shifted more to the Wolfcamp.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, maybe just an overall question on portfolio, on the broader company portfolio. At this point, are -- we've had questions about the potential for acquisitions. But are there -- is there any interest on your end in divestitures? Are international
componenttext: And then, maybe just an overall question on portfolio, on the broader company portfolio. At this point, are -- we've had questions about the potential for acquisitions. But are there -- is there any interest on your end in divestitures? Are international assets still continued core at this point? Or are there any other parts of the portfolio when you think about long-term portfolio optimization, where you could be a potential seller?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ryan, yes, we're always interested in upgrading our portfolio. And so every year, we mix in property sales in our plan. And this year is no different. 2016 will be no different. And we want to continue to divest the -- think about divesting the properties
componenttext: Ryan, yes, we're always interested in upgrading our portfolio. And so every year, we mix in property sales in our plan. And this year is no different. 2016 will be no different. And we want to continue to divest the -- think about divesting the properties that are less profitable, obviously, don't fit our CapEx requirements. We have such an enormous high graded inventory to develop. We're always wanting to evaluate the potential of our existing properties. At this point in the company, we don't really have a lot of what I would call crummy properties or not quality properties. All of our properties are fairly quality, but we're going to be looking at continuing to upgrade our portfolio as we go forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond with Simmons & Company.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, you had some good commentary, good Q&A earlier on 2016. Appreciate all that, but just trying to distill some of the earlier questions this morning. Are you saying that you think if the current strip that EOG can keep exit rate '15 productions flat n
componenttext: Bill, you had some good commentary, good Q&A earlier on 2016. Appreciate all that, but just trying to distill some of the earlier questions this morning. Are you saying that you think if the current strip that EOG can keep exit rate '15 productions flat next year, within cash flow?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's an accurate statement, Pearce. We're set up so well with the DUC inventory that even with the low prices, we would have enough cash flow to keep production flat.
componenttext: I think that's an accurate statement, Pearce. We're set up so well with the DUC inventory that even with the low prices, we would have enough cash flow to keep production flat.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is you had a good new slide in your deck about compensation factor weightings for the E&P industry. And EOG had much less emphasis on production and reserve growth than did peers. And I assume, obviously, that feeds into your decisio
componenttext: And then my follow-up is you had a good new slide in your deck about compensation factor weightings for the E&P industry. And EOG had much less emphasis on production and reserve growth than did peers. And I assume, obviously, that feeds into your decision to build the DUC inventory in the second half of this year higher than what you originally thought, and be restrained on production because of the lower price environment that we're in. However, earlier on the call, you stated that you would not have '16 production decline year-over-year at the current strip. And so if the returns for '16 aren't that great, and your compensation structure doesn't tell you to push production, why wouldn't you employ the same strategy in '16 as you're employing in the second half of this year? Or is there a mechanical reason why you don't want production to decline? Is it problematic? Or is it just strictly cash flow needs?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think next year, Pearce, what we're saying is that even with the minimum -- even with the low price cash flow scenario, the highest return investment we could make in the company would be to begin completing those DUCs and complete those DUCs earli
componenttext: Yes. I think next year, Pearce, what we're saying is that even with the minimum -- even with the low price cash flow scenario, the highest return investment we could make in the company would be to begin completing those DUCs and complete those DUCs earlier in the year versus spending that money on other things. So the quality of these DUCs is very high quality. So -- and we have infrastructure in place. So that would be the highest return place to put the money.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Irene Haas with Wunderlich.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Irene Haas with Wunderlich.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I specifically would like to ask you a question in the north of Delaware Basin. I'm noticing that these wells are really, very, very attractively priced, like $7 million D&C. So question is, is it less overpressure? How many strings of casing do you use o
componenttext: I specifically would like to ask you a question in the north of Delaware Basin. I'm noticing that these wells are really, very, very attractively priced, like $7 million D&C. So question is, is it less overpressure? How many strings of casing do you use out there? And also, this close we're looking at, are they in patch, sort of batch drilling or pad mode? Could we expect some more reduction to come in? And then, probably you alluded to something that you said earlier. In the final development scheme, would you be stacking these really prolific zones together when you go into manufacturing mode? That's probably something different from Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Irene, this is Gary Thomas. Yes, we're really pleased with the progress that we've made there in the Delaware. But I would say it's really early on, and you really -- that was really good comment there as far as, yes, it is overpressured and we're still w
componenttext: Irene, this is Gary Thomas. Yes, we're really pleased with the progress that we've made there in the Delaware. But I would say it's really early on, and you really -- that was really good comment there as far as, yes, it is overpressured and we're still working on our wellbore geometry. So we've tested several different things. We believe that we'll be able to get to a point where we're looking at a 2-string design. And just like we always do and like you've seen us do in the Eagle Ford and in the Bakken, we'll just continue to reduce those days and we'll reduce those costs. Because in the plays -- go ahead, Irene? I was just going to say yes, you look through those various plays and we reduced our days from anywhere from, oh goodness, 15% to 30% and of course, that translates to cost. We're really making a lot of progress on the completion side and cost reduction. So yes, overall, our total well cost has been reduced by about 20%. But again, it's less than the Delaware, and we're just kind of turning that on. I suppose [indiscernible]

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I was wondering, for these, the 2 wells you quoted, they're really short lateral and they got some really kind of impressive grades. And so my question for you, are you targeting pure shale? Are you looking for something a little different?
componenttext: So I was wondering, for these, the 2 wells you quoted, they're really short lateral and they got some really kind of impressive grades. And so my question for you, are you targeting pure shale? Are you looking for something a little different?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the Wolfcamp is -- I'd say it's -- we're looking at whatever the best pay target is in those, at this point in time. So in every one of these plays, as Bill mentioned earlier, we're spending a lot of time on targeting, trying to understand what the
componenttext: Well, the Wolfcamp is -- I'd say it's -- we're looking at whatever the best pay target is in those, at this point in time. So in every one of these plays, as Bill mentioned earlier, we're spending a lot of time on targeting, trying to understand what the best part of that rock is. If it's a shale, that's great. If it's not, if it's a silk stone, we look at those. So each area, the target varies and so we spent quite a bit of time trying to understand what is the best target, and then how do we best develop that. And the completion approach varies on each one of those, and the spacing approach might vary on each one of those. But in general, our target windows are getting much more narrow than they had been in the past, and we're seeing that by keeping the wellbores in the best rock longer and being able to more intensely complete those wells in that best target, productivity is better and the declines are lower.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Phillips Johnston with Capital One.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Phillips Johnston with Capital One.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is on LOE costs. We saw a nice decline in this quarter and the guidance suggests that the run rate should be in the low $6 range or so, which is also down from all of last year. We've seen most other companies report lower LOE cost as we
componenttext: My first question is on LOE costs. We saw a nice decline in this quarter and the guidance suggests that the run rate should be in the low $6 range or so, which is also down from all of last year. We've seen most other companies report lower LOE cost as well. I'm just trying to gauge how sustainable the lower trend is for you guys. It looks like the decline for EOG was less a function of fewer workovers, but rather a significant decline on the O&M front. You've referenced the impact of new infrastructure in the core of the lowest end. But can you maybe talk about which components of O&M you're seeing cost declines and how much of those savings are secular versus cyclical?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Phillips. This is Gary Thomas. I'm sure you noticed too that yes, first quarter and when you commented on that last earnings call, it was above our guidance. And our reason is we were a little bit late getting some of our infrastructure installed and
componenttext: Yes, Phillips. This is Gary Thomas. I'm sure you noticed too that yes, first quarter and when you commented on that last earnings call, it was above our guidance. And our reason is we were a little bit late getting some of our infrastructure installed and that all did come on, so we had that infrastructure in place in our major plays. A few other things yet to be done there, so as far as driving our cost down the way we have here this second quarter, it's about 1/2 through having infrastructure, maybe 1/4 of that just vendor cost reduction and other 1/4 would be just efficiency gains. So a large portion of that will be sustainable. It's just really -- we always make comments about our infrastructure and that spending. But it sure has been official for us getting our cost down and you'll notice that our chart #12 there, we're really pleased with us becoming more of a liquids company and then being able to maintain our lifting costs fairly flat. And the second...

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: That sounds good. The second question, your production guidance suggests roughly a 2% uptick in U.S. oil volumes in the fourth quarter, after 3 quarters of sequential declines. I just wanted to reconcile that uptick with the fact that you guys spent about
componenttext: That sounds good. The second question, your production guidance suggests roughly a 2% uptick in U.S. oil volumes in the fourth quarter, after 3 quarters of sequential declines. I just wanted to reconcile that uptick with the fact that you guys spent about 60% of your capital budget for the year in the first half, and you also reduced the number of expected net completions in the Eagle Ford and the Permian by about 50 wells for the year.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that kind of goes back to the time required from the point of, yes, you initiate the well or even initiate the completion, with us having several of these, a big part of our wells now are on pads. So you bring numbers of wells on. So yes, we're going t
componenttext: So that kind of goes back to the time required from the point of, yes, you initiate the well or even initiate the completion, with us having several of these, a big part of our wells now are on pads. So you bring numbers of wells on. So yes, we're going to be bringing costs down and we'll be able to maintain our production here with this second half, as we've guided. [indiscernible] go ahead.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on that, then. Are you able to say what percentage of the 405 net wells you plan to complete in Eagle Ford, Bakken, Permian, have you completed in the first half of the year?
componenttext: Just to follow-up on that, then. Are you able to say what percentage of the 405 net wells you plan to complete in Eagle Ford, Bakken, Permian, have you completed in the first half of the year?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. First half is roughly 55%. Second half is like 45%. 450.
componenttext: Yes. First half is roughly 55%. Second half is like 45%. 450.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that does conclude today's question-and-answer session. Mr. Thomas, at this time, I will turn the conference back to you for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And that does conclude today's question-and-answer session. Mr. Thomas, at this time, I will turn the conference back to you for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I do have a couple of final remarks. So first of all, just thank you for the great questions. I also want to thank all the employees of EOG for their tremendous efforts and contributions this year in making EOG successful. You've just done an outstan
componenttext:
Yes. I do have a couple of final remarks. So first of all, just thank you for the great questions. I also want to thank all the employees of EOG for their tremendous efforts and contributions this year in making EOG successful. You've just done an outstanding job. 
My final message is this. And I think you've heard it all through the call. The company is -- continues to be focused on creating long-term shareholder value and we're not chasing short-term volumes in an oversupply oil market. We're really focused on the fundamentals, improving returns, improving operating margins and building decades of high-return growth potential. So our plan -- EOG's plan is to deliver value to shareholders with high-margin, high-return production growth for years to come. So I just want to thank everybody for listening and certainly, thank you for your support.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for your participation. This does conclude today's call.
componenttext: Thank you for your participation. This does conclude today's call.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call.As a reminder, this call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Chief Fin
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call.
As a reminder, this call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone saw the press release announcing third quarter 2015 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-looking s
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone saw the press release announcing third quarter 2015 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-looking statements are outlined in the earnings release in EOG's SEC filings, and we incorporate those by reference the for this call. This conference call also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation schedules for these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures can be found on our website at www.eogresources.com. The SEC permits oil and gas companies in their filings with the SEC to disclose not only proved reserves, but also probable reserves as well as possible reserves. Some of the reserve estimates on this conference call and webcast may include potential reserves or other estimated reserves not necessarily calculated in accordance with or contemplated by the SEC's reserve reporting guidelines. We incorporate by reference the cautionary note to U.S. investors that appears at the bottom of our press release and Investor Relations page of our website.
Participating on this call this morning are: Bill Thomas, Chairman and CEO; Gary Thomas, President and Chief Operating Officer; Billy Helms, EVP, Exploration and Production; David Trice, EVP, Exploration and Production; Lance Terveen, VP, Marketing Operations; and Cedric Burgher, Senior VP, Investor and Public Relations.
An updated IR presentation was posted to our website yesterday evening, and we included guidance for the fourth quarter and full year 2015 in yesterday's press release.  
This morning, Bill Thomas will start with a few opening remarks, followed by Billy Helms 
[Audio Gap] 
Financials, capital structure and hedge position and Bill will provide concluding remarks. 
Here's Bill Thomas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. And good morning, everyone. Our goal this year has been to transition the company to be successful in a low commodity price environment. To achieve this goal, our 2015 game plan focused on the following technology and innovation, three, achie
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. And good morning, everyone. Our goal this year has been to transition the company to be successful in a low commodity price environment. To achieve this goal, our 2015 game plan focused on the following technology and innovation, three, achieve significant cost reductions through sustainable efficiency gains; four, take advantage opportunities to add drilling inventory; and five, maintain a strong balance sheet. 
As the year draws to a close, I'm pleased to report we're right on track with our plan. We're maximizing return on capital invested by directing capital to our best place: The Eagle Ford Bakken and Delaware Basin. We are having a record year of well productivity improvements and cost reductions, ongoing completions and the new work we're doing on targeting meaning EOG continues to drill the strongest horizontal wells in the industry. As a result of these efforts, our largest and best assets now generate over 40% direct after tax rate return of with $50 oil, making a solid return in horizontal oil at $50 is an excellent achievement. 
On the cost side, we're making substantial improvements. Year-over-year, third quarter per unit lease operating expense was down 17%, per unit transportation was down 11% and total G&A was down six percent.
In recent years, we've grown inventory at twice the rate of drilling. 2015 is no exception. This is a record year for adding high-quality drilling potential. Last quarter, we increased our Bakken and 3/4 net potential reserve by 600 billion barrels of oil equivalent. This quarter, we increased our Delaware Basin net potential reserves by 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent. 
As you read in our press release, we made 3 tactical acquisitions in the Delaware Basin, adding significant high-quality drilling potential. In total, we have added over 1.6 billion barrels of net reserve potential and over 3,000 net locations this year. And we've achieved this incredible growth to our reserve and drilling potential while maintaining one of the strongest balance sheets in the industry. 
To summarize our progress report, in 2015, we maximize return on capital invested, added significant future growth potential, and maintained the strong balance sheet. All year long, our focus has been on improving fundamentals and building future potential instead of chasing short-term volume growth. We believe this demonstrates that EOG's priorities are squarely focused on returns and creating long-term shareholder value. 
I will now turn the call over to Billy Helms to discuss the big news this quarter, our resource update to the Delaware Basin

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Last night, we announced a significant upgrade to our Delaware Basin assets. We increased the estimated net resource potential to 2.35 billion barrels of oil equivalent, that's a 74% increase from our resource estimate just 2 years ago. The
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Last night, we announced a significant upgrade to our Delaware Basin assets. We increased the estimated net resource potential to 2.35 billion barrels of oil equivalent, that's a 74% increase from our resource estimate just 2 years ago. The expanded resource provides 2,200 additional net new locations adding to what was already decades of drilling inventory. 
The primary driver of this upgrade is our constant focus on improving well results through the application of technology and targeting. We have a proven track record of increasing a place potential. In this quarter it our success is evident in the Wolfcamp and Second Bone Spring Sand plays. In the Wolfcamp, we are adding net potential reserves of 500 million barrels of oil equivalent and almost 1,000 net wells. We now estimate the Wolfcamp's total net potential reserves to be 1.3 billion barrels of oil equivalent from 2,050 net drilling locations. This estimate is based on the highly detailed evaluation of multiple distinct intervals within a geologically complex basin. Like other plays, we have found that by first identifying and then targeting discrete intervals, we can dramatically improve the performance of the well and ultimately the recovery from the reservoir. There are several potential targets within the Wolfcamp and we have successful tests in at least 3. This resource estimate with wells place in these intervals across all of our acreage with wells basin the that varies from 650 feet the 1,320  feet between wells in the same zone. The summarize it more simply, this resource estimate assumes at least 1 productive interval across all of our acreage with wells spaced about 700 feet apart. 
Similar to other resource plays, we are in a testing tighter spacing with encouraging results. Last quarter, we drilled a 2 well pattern on 880-foot spacing. The Dragon 36 State #701H and #702H. These wells rates average over 2,300 barrels of oil per day. This quarter, we drilled a 2 well pattern in the same area on closer spacing at 500 apart. The Brown Bear 36 State #702H and #703H. Their initial production averaged over 3,000 barrels of oil per well we are drilling wills while improving their EURs. 
Another highlight in the third quarter was the Thor 21 #702H. This is an industry record horizontal Wolfcamp well with a 30 day IP of 3,490 barrels of oil equivalent per day. All these Wolfcamp wells are in the oil window which we identified late last year. Wells in this window produce at least 50% oil versus 31% in the combo play. With this resource update, we initiated a separate Wolfcamp oil window gross EUR of 750 Mboe per well. Wells completed in the combo area maintain their previously estimated growth EUR of 900 Mboe per well. We're encouraged by these results and continue to test and evaluate tighter well spacing and pattern along with multiple targets. With approximately 2/3 of our acreage in the oil window, this play will generate very competitive returns during this period of low commodity prices. 
In the Second Bone Spring Sand we initiated our net resource potential estimate of 500 million barrels of oil equivalent and 1,250 net well locations. Like the Wolfcamp, this estimate is a result of a detailed evaluation of recent completions in multiple targets, and presented at least 1 productive target across all of our acreage. The well count constitutes actual sticks on a map locations. And while well spacing varies across the play by well and target in general, it averages about 850 feet. 
We first discussed this oil target last year and are very encouraged by initial well results. The Second Bone Spring Sand provides an attractive third leg to our Delaware Basin activity. The Leonard is the most mature of our Delaware Basin plays, in we continue to make progress improving results. Our recent 4 well package mentioned in the press release, the Hawk 35 7H through 10H was completed on 500-foot spacing with an average IP of 1,615 barrels of oil per day, these wells are producing on par with Leonard wells drilled on wider spacing last year. Again, this is a testament to the progress we've made on completion technology in the Delaware Basin. Moving forward, we expect to develop this resource using 300 and 500-foot spacing. 
We had one other significant success in the Delaware Basin last quarter. Last night, we announced that through 3 transactions, we added 2,600 net acres in Loving County Texas and Lee County New Mexico. Since the start of the year, we've mentioned our heightened interest and acquisition opportunities, driven by the oil price downcycle. While we didn't initially rule out corporate M&A, we quickly focus our efforts on targeting smaller, more tactical acquisitions. These types of opportunities are more likely to compete with our existing high-quality inventory because the acreage is mostly undeveloped and is concentrated in the core of these plays. We are already drilling this highly perspective acreage and the potential reserve estimates from these acquisitions are included in our update Delaware Basin numbers. EOG's Delaware Basin potential was rapidly increasing, and we expect this asset to be a significant top-tier contributor to the future growth of the company. 
In the Eagle Ford, after 5 years and 3 resource upgrades to this world class play, we are still excited about the learning and the technical progress we make every quarter. We continue to test and evaluate the lower Eagle Ford W pattern mentioned in last quarter's call. While the W pattern is not new to the industry, there is one significant difference to the spacing tests, their vertical spacing between target intervals is not necessarily an arbitrary distance but rather is determined by certain characteristics of the rock. Our W pattern test is specifically designed to take advantage of technical findings from the work we are doing around targeting. We started this targeting work by analyzing 60 unique rock characteristics from hundreds of recently drilled Eagle Ford wells from the 60 we identified 12 characteristics that are present in our best wells by incorporating this data in our 3D seismic and [indiscernible] data. We determined that, that lower Eagle Ford may have 2 sweet spot intervals. Please be sure to look for the flight in our IR deck that graphically demonstrates this finding. 
The laterals in our W pattern test are geo-steered to very specific areas that meet specific criteria as. These targets can be as narrow as 20 feet. Initial results from these tests are promising. As we gather more data, conduct more tests and evaluate the results, we will bring you updates. 
I'll turn it over to David Trice to discuss the Bakken and the Rockies

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Billy. In the Rockies, we continue to maximize the value of our acreage position by using enhanced completion techniques and lowering capital and operating expenses dramatically. As you may recall last quarter, we announced that we're implementing
componenttext:
Thanks, Billy. In the Rockies, we continue to maximize the value of our acreage position by using enhanced completion techniques and lowering capital and operating expenses dramatically. As you may recall last quarter, we announced that we're implementing high-density completions in some Rockies wells that are similar to the completions currently used in the Eagle Ford. While the geology varies from day to play and even within the same play, we see upside in our ability to increase value through high-density and integrated completion techniques. 
In the Bakken, we are focused on completing infield wells in our core area using our latest completion technology. Even though these infield wells are among old producing wells, our integrated completion approach ensures that we effectively simulate the reservoir and deliver high rate return at maximum value. 
An example of infill wells in our core acreage is a 3 will pad on the partial up 30 and 29 unit. This pad came online with an average initial rate of over 1,800 barrels of oil per day and 1 million cubic feet per day on rich natural gas per well. These wells are spaced just 500 feet apart and use a shorter laterals that average less than 6,000 feet. 
Our latest Bakken wells are averaging just 7.6 days spud to TD for 80 400 foot lateral and cost $7 million. This is a reduction of 20% from 2014. 
In addition, we've lowered LOE in the Bakken core area, up to $5 a barrel through infrastructure investments like water gathering systems. All of these improvements will allow us to maximize the value of this 1 billion barrel oil equivalent asset and deliver solid returns even in a low price environment. 
In the DJ Basin, we continue to refine our drilling techniques and implement high-density completions. Long-term data is needed to fully evaluate the results. However, initial data indicates improved performance. In the third quarter, we brought online a full well pad that targeted the Codell sandstone. These wells are located in the Whidbey 1705 and 1720 units and produced an average initial rate in excess of 1,100 barrels of oil per day with 600 mcf per day of rich natural gas per well, using an average lateral length of 8,700 feet. 
The recent well cost in the Codell are averaging just $7 million for 90 400 foot lateral with the latest well performance and lower well cost, the Codell is delivering a direct A-tax read return approaching 30%. As greater efficiency continues to drive down cost, we believe we can achieve a target well cost of $6.1 million. These successes in the Codell are another example of how we're transitioning EOG to be successful in a low commodity price environment. 
The Powder River Basin remains a core position for EOG. Although capital spending is lower this year, we continue to work the technical details, block up acreage and secure regulatory permits. All of this will set up the Powder River Basin as a future growth engine for EOG. 
I'll now turn it over to Tim Driggers to discuss financials and capital structure.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. For the third quarter, capitalized interest was $9.8 million. Total cash expiration and development expenditures were $970 million, excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, pr
componenttext:
Thanks, David. For the third quarter, capitalized interest was $9.8 million. Total cash expiration and development expenditures were $970 million, excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $51 million. There were $368 million of property acquisitions during the quarter. Year-to-date, total cash expiration and development expenditures were $3.7 billion, excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. Expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $253 million. 
During the third quarter, EOG incurred $4.1 billion in noncash property impairment charges net of tax. The Impairments were due to declines in the forward commodity prices and were related to some of our legacy natural gas and marginal liquid assets. 
At the end of September, total debt outstanding was $6.4 billion or debt-to-capitalization ratio of 33%. We had $743 million of cash on hand giving us a non-GAAP net debt of $5.7 billion and a net debt-to-total capital ratio of 30%. Approximately 5% of the 8% increase from the end of June was due to the noncash impairment recognized this quarter. The effective tax rate for the third quarter was 35% and the deferred tax ratio was 101%. In terms of our hedge positions, for the period November 1 through December 31, 2015, EOG has crude oil financial price swap contracts in place for 10,000 barrels of oil per day at an weighted average price of $89.98 per barrel. In addition, for November 2015, EOG has put options in place which established a floor price of $45 or 82,000 barrels of oil per day. For the month of December 2015, EOG has natural gas financial price swap contracts in place for 175,000 MMBtu per day at a weighted average price of $4.51 per MMBtu. Now I'll turn it back to Bill.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Now a quick word on the macro. Our view has not changed. The industry is becoming more disciplined. The U.S. is on an oil production declined based on EIA data and can exit the year 500,000 to 600,000 barrels of oil per day lower than peak pr
componenttext: Thanks, Tim. Now a quick word on the macro. Our view has not changed. The industry is becoming more disciplined. The U.S. is on an oil production declined based on EIA data and can exit the year 500,000 to 600,000 barrels of oil per day lower than peak production recorded in April. Worldwide, longer-term projects are being cut. Though we agree with the consensus view that $40 to $50 oil is not sustainable and supply and demand is in the process of slowly rebalancing. Regarding 2016. Although our planning process won't be complete until the beginning of the year when we have a better view of oil prices, I will share a little color on our situation. EOG is uniquely positioned for strong performance next year. We will enter 2016 with a large high-quality inventory of drill but uncompleted wells, and we have view capital commitments. Therefore, we have flexibility with respect to our CapEx program. The highest return use of our capital next year will be to complete many of our DUCs in the first half of the year. This will allow us to have a strong start to 2016. And, as always, we have no interest in outspending our discretionary cash flow. Our focus will be on increasing capital returns, increasing the quality of our inventory and reducing operating costs. 2015 is rapidly coming to a close and I could not be prouder of how the EOG team has been executing on our plan. As I said at the start of the year, I've seen many downturns in my 36 years with the company. Each time, EOG emerges on the other side and better shape. This is the exact how 2015 is playing out. There is 1 primarily take away from the call today, EOG is quickly adapting to be successful in the low oil price environment. We are not depending on a rebound to high oil prices. Instead we're making the most of the current price environment by focusing on improving fundamentals and building future potential. In fact, 2015 has been EOG's best year in terms of the magnitude of improvements in the company. Regardless of where we are in the commodity cycle, EOG is committed to return focused, capital disciplined year after year. The company remains focused on creating long-term shareholder value. Thanks for listening. And now we'll go to Q&A.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

componenttext: Why don't you touch base on the enhanced completions? It sounds like you're starting to use these in the Delaware Basin here. Obviously, you've had a lot of success in other plays. I mean, any reason to think that these both give you a nice improvement in economics here?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo, this is Billy Helms. As you mentioned, we've used these enhanced completions or these high-density completions in other place largely starting in the Eagle Ford where we have certainly demonstrated the uplift associated with executing these high
componenttext: Yes, Leo, this is Billy Helms. As you mentioned, we've used these enhanced completions or these high-density completions in other place largely starting in the Eagle Ford where we have certainly demonstrated the uplift associated with executing these high-density completions. And we are transferring this technology to other plays, including the Delaware Basin, and I think the results are very encouraging with what we're seeing there and we are incorporating our high-density completions along with our focus on targeting. And the targeting, I think is also going to be make a huge difference of the performance on the wells. I'd say in the Delaware Basin, it's still early on and we're evaluating both those 2 new approaches as well as spacing tests in each one of our target intervals. And we hope to be able to give you some very positive news in the future on the performance of those efforts.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. I guess, just turning to the Eagle Ford here. Just trying to get a sense of where you guys are at in the process of testing the W patterns of the staggered stacks here and able to kind of see any result at this point? And where do yo
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. I guess, just turning to the Eagle Ford here. Just trying to get a sense of where you guys are at in the process of testing the W patterns of the staggered stacks here and able to kind of see any result at this point? And where do you think you will have a better update on that?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms again. On the Eagle Ford, we've actually got several tests underway using this W pattern test. And the W pattern, just to make sure we are certain about the explanation of that is largely in, it is only in the lower Eagle For
componenttext: Yes, Leo. This is Billy Helms again. On the Eagle Ford, we've actually got several tests underway using this W pattern test. And the W pattern, just to make sure we are certain about the explanation of that is largely in, it is only in the lower Eagle Ford that we're doing the W pattern. So we're not -- we're just focused solely on the W pattern in the lower Eagle Ford. And that's largely been the focus, as a result of our targeting efforts as they started in the lower Eagle Ford. We identified through our analysis of all the core data and the better data that we had that there are 2 sweet spot intervals that we wanted to target. It still early on. We've just started testing those and we're testing those in several areas across the field. But we are encouraged with the early results. The early results look to indicate that these 2 areas -- these 2 sweet spot intervals aren't interfering with each other during the production phase. So that gives us a lot of encouragement for additional resource that we'll be able to capture in the future. It's still early yet to really quantify the results from that test. But I'd say we're optimistic about the results.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, let me start off on macro strategy kind of question. You guys are one of the best, if not the best unconventional operator, deep well inventory and a relatively bullish outlook on the commodity. Philosophically, with what does your re-acceleration l
componenttext: Bill, let me start off on macro strategy kind of question. You guys are one of the best, if not the best unconventional operator, deep well inventory and a relatively bullish outlook on the commodity. Philosophically, with what does your re-acceleration look like? Will the phasing activity within cash flow and neutrality on a few quarter lag? And given the efficiencies that have accelerated, I mean does it change your view on a peak rig count being significantly lower than prior rig count in a recovery scenario.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Evan, thanks for the question. Yes, I think the key for us going in next year the advantage we have that we didn't have in the early part of 2015 is we have incredible amount of flexibility with our capital. It's really, we just don't have commitments to
componenttext: Evan, thanks for the question. Yes, I think the key for us going in next year the advantage we have that we didn't have in the early part of 2015 is we have incredible amount of flexibility with our capital. It's really, we just don't have commitments to international. We don't have lease retention. We don't have as much heavy infrastructure especially first part of the year, and we don't have a lot of service contracts in place. So we're free to really put our money on the best rate of return projects or wells in the company, and we're also free to bury that capital spend rate based on the commodity price. And we can react very quickly. So as we said we're not going to give specific growth numbers or production numbers or CapEx numbers until February because we're very committed to staying within cash flow. So that will really determine our view of, basically we'll use the strip prices plus form factor that we have on the macro to kind of determine our CapEx for the year. And then we will bury that according to the commodity prices as the year goes through. So it will be a very flexible year. And a -- with our focus will be of course on increasing returns, increasing the quality of our inventory and continuing to prove up new things.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And it sounds like DUC will be your first lever there. Let me ask my second our follow-up question on the Delaware. You're making significant progress, how long do you think it takes to get to the same level of technological maturity that yo
componenttext: That's great. And it sounds like DUC will be your first lever there. Let me ask my second our follow-up question on the Delaware. You're making significant progress, how long do you think it takes to get to the same level of technological maturity that you have in the Eagle Ford where you're satisfied and your ability to drill within zone optimize completion design. I'll leave it there.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan. This is Billy Helms. Yes, for the Delaware Basin as you mentioned there, we are earlier in the ability to really get into good development program there. I think the key thing you have to realize about the Delaware Basin, as opposed to the Eagl
componenttext: Yes, Evan. This is Billy Helms. Yes, for the Delaware Basin as you mentioned there, we are earlier in the ability to really get into good development program there. I think the key thing you have to realize about the Delaware Basin, as opposed to the Eagle Ford is the Delaware Basin is a highly complex basin. The geology changes quite a bit across the basin. There are multiple targets, multiple formations and we're -- we've done -- our team has done a great job on really delineating their understanding of the play with the data that we have. And we're always collecting more and more date as we develop the program. So I'd say just to boil it down to maybe baseball terms, we're probably about third inning on the Delaware Basin as opposed to sixth or seventh inning may be on the Eagle Ford for instance.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd like to dig in a bit on the advanced completions in the well productivity that you guys cited as one of the reasons for your oil volumes coming in over guidance. I know that the most prominent thing we see is these IP rates you guys are turning in, bu
componenttext: I'd like to dig in a bit on the advanced completions in the well productivity that you guys cited as one of the reasons for your oil volumes coming in over guidance. I know that the most prominent thing we see is these IP rates you guys are turning in, but the other thing that I believe you mentioned and we certainly see with the results on these Thor wells is not particularly for those the Thor well, the 30 day rate is at least is as remarkable as the IP rate. And I'm curious, when you look at the effect that these advanced completions are having on your production profile, should we be thinking about 3Q being a function of wells completed in 3Q? Or is it more a function of the wells that were completed in the first half of the year that are not -- of our holding back better with a decline that we are leading to things like this.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles, this is Billy Helms. I think that's a good question. I think it's maybe a factor of both. Certainly, the targeting and the high-density completions are making a huge difference, as evidenced in what you just mentioned in the Thor well and th
componenttext: Yes, Charles, this is Billy Helms. I think that's a good question. I think it's maybe a factor of both. Certainly, the targeting and the high-density completions are making a huge difference, as evidenced in what you just mentioned in the Thor well and the other Wolfcamp wells we completed in the last quarter. And certainly, those our new wells and we're seeing vast improvements in the productivity of the wells. And they are sustaining themselves, as evidenced by the 30 day average that you mentioned on the Farwell. And we've been doing this for a while longer in some of the other plays, mainly on the Eagle Ford and guess, we are seeing the decline is not as deep on those wells. So it has an overall flattening effect on our decline rates on all these programs. So we're seeing the benefit in those 2 areas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

componenttext: Okay, got it. So it's both. And then if I could ask a question about the Delaware Basin acquisitions. I know that this is a little bit of a change of MO from you guys, you've been historically focused on organically saying these acquisitions, further acquisition as the closest you get in the Delaware Basin given the legacy of vertical production out there? And I suppose as a follow-on to that shouldn't be expecting more similarly sized deals from you guys going forward?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Charles, this Bill. I think, unless Billy commented a bit done that, but I think it'll be a combination. We're doing a lot of little deals along with the bigger deals and so we're blocking up acreage sharing acreage with other operators and swapping it ou
componenttext: Charles, this Bill. I think, unless Billy commented a bit done that, but I think it'll be a combination. We're doing a lot of little deals along with the bigger deals and so we're blocking up acreage sharing acreage with other operators and swapping it out and some drilled and then we're also buying some small tracks from different operators. So it'll be a combination of multiple things. As Billy said, we pretty much ruled out any of the bigger M&A possibilities. And mainly we ruled that out on asset quality. It didn't come in comparable to what we already have. So we don't really expect to be presenting anything like that. Billy you want to add anything?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing that I would add, Charles, to that is I think that we are -- the acquisitions that we had done and is largely staying within our focus of growing organically. The difference would be is that organic growth in new plays we're still able
componenttext: Yes, the only thing that I would add, Charles, to that is I think that we are -- the acquisitions that we had done and is largely staying within our focus of growing organically. The difference would be is that organic growth in new plays we're still able to go out and get ahead of the competition and require positions in new plays fairly cheaply. In the Delaware Basin, it's a very mature Basin a lot of ownership legacy ownerships have been out there for years and years as everybody knows. So one way to gain entry into the acreage that we see quite a bit of upside is through these tactical acquisitions. And I would add to Bill's comment, we are being highly selective in what we acquire. So we passed up several opportunities that had been transacted that we just passed on. And we did focus on these 3 tactical acquisitions that we are very encouraged with. And as a matter of fact, we already have drilling operations going on these, on the acreage that we acquired. So we're going to stay selective and continue to grow each one of these plays in whatever manner we feel like we can.

componenttext: Yes, question on the acquisitions. These -- who were the counter parties? Were they privates or publics or landowners?

componenttextpreview: They were selective companies and we're not going to get into details about the deals we have done. And certainly not getting into the details about the things we've looked on. Its is something that we don't really comment on. But I would say there's stro
componenttext: They were selective companies and we're not going to get into details about the deals we have done. And certainly not getting into the details about the things we've looked on. Its is something that we don't really comment on. But I would say there's strong companies strong companies we've done business with in the past and hope to continue to do business with in the future. And we're looking at all the opportunities whether smaller private companies or larger public companies for opportunities to add to our positions.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a follow-up on next year. How do you think about debt to cap? And is that on a level that you're happy with? Or is some of next year's cash flow going to debt reduction?
componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up on next year. How do you think about debt to cap? And is that on a level that you're happy with? Or is some of next year's cash flow going to debt reduction?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, Bob. We're very committed to keeping a very strong balance sheet. So we'll not stretch it much further than it really is. Although I will say this, we will continue to look for acquisitions and not likely to find a big one. But if we find thing
componenttext: Well, yes, Bob. We're very committed to keeping a very strong balance sheet. So we'll not stretch it much further than it really is. Although I will say this, we will continue to look for acquisitions and not likely to find a big one. But if we find things that are attractive to us, we will use, evaluate all the options that we have to acquire that. And so the company's in fantastic shape to do that. Of course the goal is for us -- has always been to generate free cash flow, to continue working on the dividend down the road too. We need a little bit better commodity price than we have right now to accomplish that. But that will be a goal for us going forward. We also continue to market non-core properties. That's been an ongoing process for the company for years. So we're in the process of doing that again this year too. So we've got multiple ways to continue to keep the net debt of the company low, and to really preserve our balance sheet.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, within the scheme of living within cash flow, obviously, you've had fairly large international project pretty much close to conclusion now. A lot of exploration spending and I guess, a fair amount of midstream spending. So just in the grand scheme o
componenttext: Bill, within the scheme of living within cash flow, obviously, you've had fairly large international project pretty much close to conclusion now. A lot of exploration spending and I guess, a fair amount of midstream spending. So just in the grand scheme of things, within the different buckets, can you generalize whether you will see an incremental swing back towards completions within the context of living within cash flow in terms of your CapEx spending.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. So specifically, yes, for 2016 with the very large uncompleted well inventory, certainly the focus of the CapEx -- and that will be the highest return thing we can invest in next year will be on completing that inventory and lower net inventory
componenttext: Yes, Doug. So specifically, yes, for 2016 with the very large uncompleted well inventory, certainly the focus of the CapEx -- and that will be the highest return thing we can invest in next year will be on completing that inventory and lower net inventory down. So it gives us a lot of flexibility because we just don't have all these other big commitments, and that will certainly give us, I think stronger capital efficiency very, very high return on our capital next year.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, not to push the point though, but I guess, I was kind of hoping you might quantify order of magnitude relative to exploration, Irish Sea midstream, I'm guessing it's close to 20% 25% of this year's budget. I mean, could it be that big of a swing
componenttext: I guess, not to push the point though, but I guess, I was kind of hoping you might quantify order of magnitude relative to exploration, Irish Sea midstream, I'm guessing it's close to 20% 25% of this year's budget. I mean, could it be that big of a swing in terms of incremental completion capital?

componenttextpreview: No, I think the -- we call that kind of the indirect. That will be roughly about the same percentage that it has been in the past. Maybe not quite as much in the first part of the year. But certainly, we've got things that we need to do in those areas. As
componenttext: No, I think the -- we call that kind of the indirect. That will be roughly about the same percentage that it has been in the past. Maybe not quite as much in the first part of the year. But certainly, we've got things that we need to do in those areas. As far as international projects, we don't have many significant commitments next year on international. It's actually less, I think, than historically. Let me ask Gary Thomas to kind of chime in and give you a little bit more color on that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Doug, one thing on the indirects, and you talk about the midstream will be benefit next year with us having these DUCs because of they're in the areas where we have quite a lot of operations currently. So we'll have less infrastructure requirements just t
componenttext: Doug, one thing on the indirects, and you talk about the midstream will be benefit next year with us having these DUCs because of they're in the areas where we have quite a lot of operations currently. So we'll have less infrastructure requirements just to hope those wells up. So it would be a little less than what we've experienced in 2014, 2015.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

componenttextpreview: Let me run with that same theme. If I think about maintenance CapEx, I think you guys are doing a number before $4.8 billion, one, is that the right number? And then two, obviously, that number goes lower. Can you give us any framework around that?
componenttext: Let me run with that same theme. If I think about maintenance CapEx, I think you guys are doing a number before $4.8 billion, one, is that the right number? And then two, obviously, that number goes lower. Can you give us any framework around that?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's -- when you look at forward spending now and that came back and we're looking at spending $1 billion this quarter and probably somewhere around maybe $900 million for next quarter this fourth quarter. So it could be talked all of us being maintenan
componenttext: That's -- when you look at forward spending now and that came back and we're looking at spending $1 billion this quarter and probably somewhere around maybe $900 million for next quarter this fourth quarter. So it could be talked all of us being maintenance capital. But yet, when we go into '16, we'll not have to be spending money associated with locations, with the drilling, with quite a lot associated view these DUCs. So that'll probably reduce per well about 30%. But the $4.8 billion is -- we're -- our maintenance capital is quite a bit less from that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that was the prior number. Okay. That's helpful. And if I think about the DUC, the base of the DUC drawdown, I think before we talked about midyear, are you is going to take them down kind of should we think about it systematically taking down 200
componenttext: I think that was the prior number. Okay. That's helpful. And if I think about the DUC, the base of the DUC drawdown, I think before we talked about midyear, are you is going to take them down kind of should we think about it systematically taking down 200 over the first 6 months of the year? How should the -- can you give us any framework around just the pace and timing of that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. Let me answer that one. We have a lot of flexibility. So really the pace of our spending and the pace of the our activity will be very much guided by the commodity price and the resulting cash flow. So that's a reason we're not giving really a
componenttext: Yes, David. Let me answer that one. We have a lot of flexibility. So really the pace of our spending and the pace of the our activity will be very much guided by the commodity price and the resulting cash flow. So that's a reason we're not giving really any details because we want to work our plan more. Every time we work our plan, it gets a little better. So we're very encouraged about that. And then we certainly need to have a lot better insight on what the cash flow and commodity price would be. So it'll be regulated by really the oil price.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
